items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details: The District employs non-bargaining unit employees in various categories to support programs and services.  These categories are: short-term assignments with limitations as defined in the CSEA/District collective bargaining agreement; substitutes to fill positions for employees on leave of absence or in vacant positions; professional experts with specialized knowledge or expertise not generally required of, or found within, the employee classifications established by the Governing Board; and athletic support staff for athletic activities.

items.item_details:
Education Code 81655 stipulates that no contract is an enforceable obligation of the District until it has been approved by the Board of Trustees. Board Policy 6100 establishes the authority of certain administrators to approve contracts under the bid limit prior to formal Board approval. All contracts, purchase orders and contract revisions exceeding the current bid limit of $86,000 shall have prior Board approval as a separate board item.
	 
This consent item presents for Board approval: all purchase orders for this period, which includes purchase orders for administratively approved contracts exceeding $1,000, as well as additional contracts, although not executed by way of purchase order, are deemed appropriate to be added by the Purchasing Department.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees ratify the contracts, purchase orders and contract revisions for the period of April 10, 2015 through May 9, 2015 as noted in the attached documents.

items.item_details:
A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve out of country travel for students, Rebecca Bruno, Tasean Clark, Audreya Deshazier, Kenny Jackson, Nancy Macias, Derrick Newton, Darrell Parker-Rogers,  Sophia Said, Jocelyne Salazar, Yesenia Santos, Christopher, Sifflet, Henry Simmons, and Christine Tellez for a study abroad trip to Cuba.  Students will be accompanied by Evergreen Valley College faculty members, Keenan Norris, Flora Payne, Charlie Kahn-Lomax, and Alexandria White.  
	 
The students will leave San Francisco, California on Saturday, July 25, 2015 and will be returning on Wednesday, August 5, 2015. The estimated cost for travel is $31,850.00 ($2,450 per person).    
	 
The purpose of this trip is to grant an opportunity to travel abroad to those who might not otherwise have such an opportunity.  This includes; economically disadvantaged students, students of color, and students who are single parents in the San Jose Evergreen Community College District.  The primary objective is to globalize their understanding of the western world historically, culturally, geographically, and economically. Students will be required to register in 3-units of college coursework (i.e. African American Literature or Introduction to Ethnic Studies) during the summer of 2015.  Prior to the trip, students will receive numerous lectures on world history, global economics and geography.  While on the study abroad tour students will receive numerous lectures and field study projects from university faculty.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve out of country travel for Evergreen Valley College students and faculty.
items.item_text: Students Out of Country Travel
items.item_text_raw: 10. Students Out of Country Travel

items.item_details: The California Community College Chancellor's Office (CCCO) recently entered into an agreement with InCommon to cover the registration fees and annual costs for each of the California Community College Districts to participate. InCommon is operated by Internet2 and provides a "secure and privacy-preserving trust fabric for research and higher education, and their partners, in the United States". The CCCO will use InCommon to provide secure single sign-on access to new statewide resources such as Common Assessment, Common Course Management System (Canvas), Education Planning, Degree Audit, Retention (Hobsons/Starfish), Portal, CCCApply, and all systemwide technology when released. InCommon membership qualifies the district to purchase security certificates and other security resources at reduced costs. Additionally, the district can use InCommon to provide secure single sign-on access to other InCommon participant vendors (e.g., EBSCO, National Student Clearinghouse, Microsoft).
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the InCommon Participation Agreement and Addendum with InCommon at no cost to the District.
items.item_text: InCommon Participation Agreement and Addendum for Federated Identity Management Services
items.item_text_raw: 11. InCommon Participation Agreement and Addendum for Federated Identity Management Services

items.item_details:
San Jose City College received notice from St. Elizabeth's Day Home (“St. Elizabeth”) announcing that they will cease Child Care Provider services on June 30, 2015.  Currently, SJCC has two service contracts with the State of California (CCTR-4284 and CSPP-4540) and SJCC has a sub-contract for the service with St. Elizabeth. 
	 
We worked with St. Elizabeth, Dean Sean Abel, faculty, District Office staff, and the State to determine the best approach to find another sub-contractor.  After completing the RFP process, and doing our due diligence, the College selected Estrella Family Services as the provider with the “best value” for the College.  The contract is for one year to evaluate the services.
	 
The Board is asked to approve the issuance of the contract to Estrella Family Services of $301,940.40 for Child Care Provider services.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve an Independent Contractor Agreement (ICA) in the amount of $301,940.40 to Estrella Family Services.
items.item_text: Estrella Family Services Independent Contractor Agreement
items.item_text_raw: 12. Estrella Family Services Independent Contractor Agreement

items.item_details:
The San Jose Evergreen Community College District, through Workforce Institute, has been awarded a $13,173,153 CCPT regional collaborative grant to create and expand Science Technology Engineering Math (STEM) in the Silicon Valley’s K12 through community colleges.  The regional collaboration will link students, beginning in middle school, with career awareness, through in high school career preparation, leading to accelerated, contextual STEM foundation skills and work based learning, with access to paid internships at community colleges in three high-demand, high-wage industry sectors: computer science, engineering and advanced manufacturing. The SVETP collaboration consists of 9 community colleges and 10 unified school districts and alternative charter schools, 3 CSUs, 3 workforce investment boards, 20 employers, a workforce intermediary and UCLA’s Higher Education Research Institute (HERI), as an independent evaluator that will increase sustainability. 
	 
The three career pathways were selected to respond to regional employers’ need for a skilled native workforce to fill current openings that require STEM literacy and advanced STEM knowledge, in careers such as: software development, network administration, cybersecurity, engineering technology, biomanufacturing, machining & forming, biotech manufacturing, and laser techs. SVETP provides regional employers with the diverse STEM, locally-grown, workforce they need and provides community college students with unprecedented access to careers in high-wage, high-demand jobs previously reserved for university students.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the California Career Pathways Trust Grant Award for the regional Silicon Valley Engineering Tech Pathways (SVETP) project for the two year term: July 1, 2015 – June 30, 2017.
items.item_text: Workforce Institute – California Career Pathways Trust (CCPT) Grant Award for the Silicon Valley Engineering Tech Pathways (SVETP) Project
items.item_text_raw: 13. Workforce Institute – California Career Pathways Trust (CCPT) Grant Award for the Silicon Valley Engineering Tech Pathways (SVETP) Project

items.item_details:
On August 26, 2014, the Board of Trustees approved an Agreement to Blach Construction Company in the amount of $41,639,729 to provide construction services for the South Campus Development Project #32107 at Evergreen Valley College.
Construction contracts commonly experience unforeseen conditions or District request design changes that require an adjustment to the contract scope, price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Change Order No. 007 includes Work of adding:  power to automatic restroom door operators, providing an area drain beneath a light well, augmented curtain wall attachments at skylight areas, and revised elevator room door sizes.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.  
	 
Original Contract Amount                   $41,639,729.00
Previous Approved Changes              $     423,058.64
Change Order No. 007                       $       19,820.21   
Total Contract and Changes               $42,082,607.85
	 
The net change to Blach Construction Company’s contract as a result of all changes issued is $442,878.85 which equates to 1.06% of the original contract.  This change will be funded from the project contingency established in the project budget.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 007 in the amount of $19,820.21 to Blach Construction Company for the South Campus Development Project #32107 at Evergreen Valley College.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Evergreen Valley College South Campus Development Project #32107 – Blach Construction Company
items.item_text_raw: 2. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Evergreen Valley College South Campus Development Project #32107 – Blach Construction Company

items.item_details:
This project will upgrade the existing Cedro Electrical Transformer and the Physical Education Fan Coil Unit that is beyond its useful life.  Because the estimated project cost was greater than the allocated State Scheduled Maintenance funding, and to assure a complete set of projects, the campus bond managers agreed to supplement the State Scheduled Maintenance funds with Measure G-2010 Bond funds.  The Board has previously approved a contract to TMAD Taylor Gaines to provide design services for the Cedro Transformer and PE FCU Upgrade.  
	 
The project was posted on the District’s purchasing website, advertised in local papers on April 28, 2015 and May 5, 2015 and published at local builders’ exchanges and plan rooms.  In addition, invitations to bid were sent to over fifty contractors including small, minority and woman-owned firms.  On May 26, 2015, construction bids were received from the five pre-qualified General Contractors for the Cedro Transformer and PE FCU Upgrade project.  Base bids were received as follows:
	 
GA Technical Services                                     $415,500
Integra Construction Services, Inc.                  $589,608
JKL                                                                   $593,254
Environmental Systems (ESI)                          $671,000
Blocka Construction                                         $714,000
	 
After a thorough technical review by Gilbane, the 1st lowest bidder GA Technical Services withdrew their bid based on a mathematical clerical error.  A subsequent technical review of Integra Construction Services from Pleasanton, CA was determined to be the 2nd lowest responsive and responsible bidder.
	 
Public Contract Code sections 5100 through 5110 address the issue of bid mistakes. Under Section 5101, a bidder is entitled to relief from its bid due to a mistake if the awarding authority consents to allow the bidder to withdraw its bid.  Public contract Code 5103 further defines that a bidder may be relieved of its bid due to mistake when:  (a) A mistake was made.  (b) He or she gave the public entity written notice within five working days, excluding Saturdays, Sundays, and state holidays, after the opening of the bids of the mistake, specifying in the notice in detail how the mistake occurred.  (c) The mistake made the bid materially different than he or she intended it to be. (d) The mistake was made in filling out the bid and not due to error in judgment or to carelessness in inspecting the site of the work, or in reading the plans or specifications.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the award of a contract in the amount of $589,608.00 to Integra Construction Services, Inc. for the Cedro Transformer and PE FCU Upgrade Project #32307-08 at Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_details:
The scope of this Agreement is to provide a Facility Condition Assessment (FCA) for Evergreen Valley College (EVC).  The assessment will provide evaluation and documentation of the general condition of the buildings, including life safety, mechanical, electrical, and plumbing systems, and site improvements.  The scope includes an electronic database that will include cost estimates for maintenance and repairs, expected useful life, remaining useful life, and a comparison of costs to repair or replace systems and components.  This project implements the FCA data into the Fusion/Onuma System, which is the State Chancellorâs Office sponsored asset management system.
	 
The Request for Qualifications and Proposal (RFQ/RFP) for the FCA was posted on the Districtâs purchasing website and advertised in local papers on February 10, 2015 and February 17, 2015.  Seven firms submitted qualifications, as well as sealed fee proposals.  The selection process had two phases:  1) Evaluate and score the qualifications and completeness of each firm relative to the RFQ published by the District.  2) Select the top three firms to for interviews. The top three firms selected to continue with the interview phase of the selection process were ISES, Facility Engineering Associates and EMG.  The interviews for each firm included a presentation of the database system proposed,assessment of fee proposals and Q&A with the selection team with representatives from consisted of District Purchasing, District Facilities and Maintenance, EVC CTSS staff and San Jose City College staff.  Gilbane facilitated the RFQ/RFP process, meetings, scoring/ranking, and the selection process.
 
Upon completion of the interviews, the selection team ranked each firm for best value to the District.  Criteria used to rank the firms included: cost, work plan, staffing, experience, and data information systems, and reports.  The committee recommends EMG to provide the FCA, based on their completeness of their proposal, experience of key staff,  experience performing similar efforts on other projects, quality of data collection and quality of reports.  The final scope of services was reviewed and negotiated between District representatives, EMG and Gilbane, resulting in the recommended fee of $259,100.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the award of an Independent Contractor Agreement in the amount of $259,100 to Clampett Industries LLC, Dba EMG, for the Facility Condition Assessment, #32307-01 Schedule Maintenance-Small Projects.

items.item_details:
The scope of this Agreement is for the upgrading of electrical and mechanical equipment to facilitate the construction of a twenty booth welding workshop. The project will include; the assembly of twenty welding booths, installation of a fume extraction system, refurbishment of an existing room into a new work-experience office, refurbishment of an existing room into a new classroom and the construction of an outdoor steel assembly yard. The project will also include a bid alternate for the replacement of concrete to comply with ADA requirements including accessible parking and accessible access to Building 100 and Building 200.
The project was posted on the District’s purchasing website and advertised in local papers on April 28, 2015 and May 05, 2015. It was published at local builders’ exchanges and plan rooms.  In addition, invitations to bid were sent to many contractors including small minority and woman-owned firms.  On May 28, 2015 construction bids were received as follows:
           
Company Name
Base Bid ($)
					 
					 
	 
ICC General contractors Inc.
$781,982.00
					 
					 
Swenson & Associates
$780,000.00
					 
					 
R.C. Benson & Sons Inc.
$704,000.00
					 
					 
JKL Construction Services Inc.
$706,875.00
					 
					 
	 
	 
	 
Pursuant to a technical review of the bids received, RC Benson was determined to be the lowest responsive and responsible bidder with a base bid amount of $704,000. In addition, the bid documents included Additive Alternate #1 to replace existing concrete walkways which RC Benson bid in the amount of $213,500.  RCBenson’s combined base bid with Additive Alternate #1 is $917,500, which is within the District's stated construction budget of $1.1M.  We recommend that the Board, award a contract in the amount of $917,500 inclusive of the alternate pricing to ensure timely completion of the work before the start of the Fall 2015 classes.

items.item_details:
The scope of the Campus Parking and Pathway Improvements project includes rehabilitation of the South West parking lots and the replacement of various concrete walkways throughout the campus at SJCC to promote enhanced vehicular and pedestrian traffic flow, safety and accessibility. 
	 
The project was posted on the District’s purchasing website and advertised in local papers on April 29, 2015 and May 6, 2015. It was also published at local builders’ exchanges and plan rooms and invitations to bid were sent to over 180 contractors including small minority and woman-owned firms.  On May 26, 2015
construction bids were received as follows:
	 
            O’Grady Paving, Inc.                           $395,000.00
            Lewis and Tibbitts, Inc.                        $447,075.48
            Wattis Construction Co. Inc.                $581,797.00
	 
A technical review of the bids determined that the apparent low bidder, O’Grady Paving from San Jose, California, failed to include an acknowledgement of the Construction Careers Agreement by one of their sub-contractors, and as a result, their bid was determined to be non-responsive. 
	 
The second lowest bidder, Lewis and Tibbetts, was determined to be the lowest responsive and responsible bidder in the amount of $447,075.48.

On November 15, 2014 the Board agreed to enter into a contract with Anderson Brule Architects, Inc. to (professional services) develop programming and schematic design documents of the interior and exterior signage plan for the District Office Relocation Project at 40 South Market Street, San Jose.
	 
Project Assignment Amendment No. DO-01 includes six (6) additional meetings/workshops.  Because of the significance of the signage, six (6) additional meetings will be added to ensure all interested parties have an opportunity for input on the signage program for the new District Office.  The proposal was reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
The item in this amendment results in an additional cost of $15,490.00 to the contract.

As presented at the October 22, 2013 Board meeting, the District and Colleges had a few critical Measure G-2004 funded projects that were in need of construction management assistance.  On November 12, 2013 the Board approved a contract amendment for December 1, 2013 through June 30, 2014 with Gilbane in the amount of $736,415 to provide construction management services on the remaining Measure G-2004 bond projects (listed below):
	 
Joint Use 21st Century Education Center (Milpitas) 
	 
Physical Education Building (SJCC)
	 
Central Green/Arts Plaza (EVC)
	 
On June 10, 2014 the Board approved a contract amendment for Fiscal Year 2014/2015 with Gilbane in the amount of $980,785 to manage the remaining Measure G-2004 bond projects.  Gilbaneâs services for Fiscal Year 2014/2015 will come in under the original budget by approximately $200,000.
	 
The budget for Measure G-2004 construction management services is accounted for in each of the remaining project budgets in the Measure G-2004 bond program.
	 
ATTACHMENTS:
Amendment #08 to the Agreement for Program and Construction Management Services
Measure G-2004 FY 2014/2015 Contract Staffing Plan with Actual Hours through April 2015

items.item_details:
The District successfully passed Measure G-2010 on November 2, 2010.  On January 25, 2011 a facilities and bonds study session served as an opportunity to share a framework for success for Measure G-2010.  Included in this framework was the recommendation that the District utilize a program and construction management firm to provide program and construction management services to the colleges and District to support implementation of various construction and deferred maintenance projects.  In keeping with the District’s desire to promote accountability, efficiency and cost effectiveness, the District went through a formal Request for Qualifications process to seek the services of a Program and Construction Management firm to provide system-wide coordination and oversight of all capital improvement work performed under the Measure G-2010 bond program.  Gilbane Building Company was selected through this process. 
	 
Since the initial one-year contract with Gilbane awarded by the Board on May 10, 2011, policies and procedures for operating under the Bond have been implemented, overall program and detailed project scheduling has been established and maintained, accounting and purchasing procedures have been put in place and numerous projects have commenced design and are in construction at the campuses and the District. 
	 
On June 12, 2012 the Board approved the second year (FY2012/2013) contract renewal with Gilbane in the amount of $4,646,050. On June 11, 2013 the Board approved the third year (FY2013/2014) contract renewal with Gilbane in the amount of $5,627,569.  On June 10, 2014 the Board approved the fourth year (FY2014/2015) contract renewal with Gilbane in the amount of $5,724,420.
	 
Overall the Program Management budget for the life of the bond program has been established at 3% of the program budget.  Approval of the fifth year amendment stays within this 3% allocation.  Overall the Construction Management budget for the life of the bond program has been established at 10% of the construction budget.  Approval of the fifth year amendment stays within this 10% allocation.  Note that as was the case for years one, two, and three of the agreement, Gilbane’s services for year four will come in under the original budget by approximately $450,000.
	 
Note too that the basic services and contract terms and conditions remain unchanged.
	 
  ATTACHMENTS:
Amendment #07 to the Agreement for Program and Construction Management Services
Executed Agreement for Program Management/Construction Management Services (BPO #8856)
Measure G-2010 Program Management Forecasted Fee Graph
Measure G-2010 Construction Management Forecasted Fee Graph
Measure G-2010 Spending Plan Graph (through March 31, 2015)
Measure G-2010 FY 2014/2015 Contract Staffing Plan with actual hours through April 2015
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the fifth year renewal of Gilbane’s PM/CM agreement for fiscal year 2015/2016 for the not-to-exceed amount of $5,297,131.

items.item_details:
Government Code Section 7908(c) requires each community college district to report its appropriation limit to the State Chancellor of Community Colleges at least annually.
	 
The appropriation limit must be approved by the Board of Trustees in accordance with Government Code Section 7910.
	 
After the Board of Trustees approves the appropriation limit, the GANN will be reported on the Annual Financial and Budget Report (CCFS-311) to the State Chancellor of Community Colleges, which is due in October 2015.

The San Jose-Evergreen Community College District office has moved to its new location at 40 S. Market St. and is looking to establish its identity within downtown San Jose through the use of branding and external signage. The District selected Anderson Brule Architects to assist in the development of a signage master plan which will represent the complete vision for external signage and branding for its new headquarters. The implementation of the final approved plan will be conducted in a phased approach depending on the priority and cost of each element of the plan. 
	 
The Project Team worked together to identify the projectâs goals and to develop a project development process map and has already facilitated several meetings and workshops. The attached presentation represents the work to date on the project and seeks to solicit feedback from the Trustees on the path forward.

On September 10, 2013, the Board approved a contract with Impact Sciences, Inc. to prepare an Environmental Impact Report (EIR) and to provide associated mitigation monitoring program services for the Joint-Use 21st Century Post-Secondary Education Center.
	 
Impact Sciences, Inc. developed a draft EIR. In accordance with California law, this draft EIR was presented to the public by notices and public hearings. Comments received during the comment period were incorporated into the Final EIR. In accordance with California law, a “Findings of Fact” has been prepared. The Final EIR and the Finding of Facts are now presented to the Board for certification and approval by the District.

The Tentative Budget is provided as an attachment to this item and also can be accessed on the District's web site.

items.item_details:
The accreditation requirements for performance evaluations state:
	 
“  STANDARD III A.1.b
The institution assures the effectiveness of its human resources by
evaluating all personnel systematically and at stated intervals. The
institution establishes written criteria for evaluating all personnel,
including performance of assigned duties and participation in
institutional responsibilities and other activities appropriate to their
expertise. Evaluation processes seek to assess effectiveness of
personnel and encourage improvement. Actions taken following
evaluations are formal, timely, and documented.” 
 
  
MSC members raised the concern that the current evaluation process for administrators was not an effective means  to evaluate management personnel. It is inadequate in addressing the assessment of performance of assigned duties and participation in
institutional responsibilities and other activities appropriate to the individual's expertise. The current evaluation processes does not sufficiently support the assessment of personnel and encourage improvement.
 
During the academic year 2014-15, District staff and MSC membership worked collaboratively to re-examine the process and develop a cycle of evaluation for administrators that spans a six year period to support the assessment of performance and to encourage improvement.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve MSC Handbook - Administrator Performance Evaluation Cycle - Section 15 (New).

items.item_details:
Board of Trustees to have an open discussion regarding a process to appoint community members to the Chancellor Search Committee. 
 A suggested process would include a call for nominations to be sent to Citizens Bond Oversight Committee, the SJECCD Foundation Board, advisory boards of the colleges, and the community engagement contacts. The call would include a statement on the required commitment to be made if selected, due date, and notification date.
	 
Nomination responses would include individual's name, affiliation, brief statement of interest and acknowledgement of accepting the responsibilities of a committee member.
 
The Board Committee, Chancellor Search would be charged with the review and selection/appointment  of the  three 
community members.
 
Staff would issue the call, receive and collect nominations and be responsible for communication with nominees.

items.item_details: The Board has scheduled regular updates to the Ends Policy Dashboard through quarterly Monitoring Reports.  At this meeting, the Board will hear a presentation about two ends policies: (1) Career Development and (2) Transferability.  With this monitoring report the Board will have an opportunity to drill into the data related to these two policies with disaggregated data and trends. The goal of this presentation is to 1) share where District is in relation to the dashboard targets; 2) analyze the areas of strength and opportunities for improvement within the Ends Policies of Career Development and Transferability; and 3) set direction as to the areas of focus that should be the priority of the District as it relates to specified Ends Policies.  The Ends Policy Monitoring Report can support the District in making data-informed decisions and to establish priorities for the allocation fiscal and human resources to meet the goals measured in the Board Ends Policies.
items.item_text: Board Ends Policy Monitoring Report: Career Development; Transferability
items.item_text_raw: 1. Board Ends Policy Monitoring Report: Career Development; Transferability

items.item_details:
On April 2, 2015, the California Community Colleges Chancellor's Office formally notified it's districts and colleges within the system of the requirement "that each college develop, adopt and post a goals framework as mandated by recently enacted legislation."  Education Code section 84754.6 established a new system of indicators and goals intended to encourage colleges to adopt and institutional effectiveness plan that includes measuring IE metrics based upon targets set by the institution.  The Board of Governors adopted this goals framework at its March 16, 2015 meeting.  Pursuant to the Student Success and Support Program and in order to continue receiving funds from such, each college must adopt goals in the following four areas:  student performance and outcomes; accreditation status, fiscal viability, and programmatic compliance with state and federal guidelines.  The Chancellor's office is requiring that the goals within this framework be locally determined and posted to the IEPI portal according to deadlines set by the BOG.  The BOG requires that the State Chancellor post these goals by June 30, 2015 and before each fiscal year thereafter.  Thus, local college/district goals must also be posted by June 30, 2015. 
	 
For this first year, the Chancellor's Office will require districts to adopt only four goals: Course Completion Rate; Accreditation Status; Fund Balance; and Overall Audit Opinion.  SJECCD has chosen to be proactive and report goals in all required AND optional areas within the framework.  After a thorough vetting through the constituencies at each college as well as the district office, the IEPI goals for SJECCD, Evergreen Valley College, and San Jose City College for all required and optional indicators have been determined and is attached.  The Board is being asked to review these indicators and then adopt them through action at a subsequent meeting.

Administrative Procedure 5520 Student Discipline Procedures:  Violations of Student Conduct is submitted for the purpose of informing the Board of Trustees of its existence.  As a reminder, the Board approves all Board Policies while the Chancellor approves all Administrative Procedures.    
	 
Administrative Procedure (AP) 5520 and 3 accompanying documents: Student Discipline Flow Chart, Student Incident Referral Form and Student Grievance Form were presented to District Council for review and distribution to constituent groups as a course of normal process.  After suggested feedback, this procedure was approved by the Chancellor at the final District Council meeting on May 13, 2015.  
	 
The Student Incident Referral Form and Student Grievance Form can be completed and printed along with AP 5520 and the Student Discipline Flow Chart at:  http://www.sjeccd.edu/Chancellor/Documents/AdministrativeProcedures_Chapter5_StudentServices.pdf

items.item_details:
Assembly Bill 1433 (signed into law 9/30/14) mandates that all Colleges, by July 1, 2015, adopt and implement written policies and procedures to ensure that any report of a Part 1 violent crime, sexual assault or hate crime is forwarded to the appropriate law enforcement agency without identifying the victim.  
	 
The attached board policy is in line with this legal mandate and submitted to the Board as a first read. This draft policy, along with the accompanying administrative procedure, was presented to District Council and shared with constituent groups with final feedback received on May 13, 2015.  
	 
The included administrative procedure is provided to the board for information only, not for review, as the board approves board policies and the Chancellor approves administrative procedures. 
	 
Both BP 3540 and AP 3540 will be presented again at the next SJECCD Board meeting with a recommendation for approval in order to meet the July 1 deadline.
items.item_text: Board Policy & Administrative Procedure 3540: Sexual and Other Assaults on Campus- first reading
items.item_text_raw: 5. Board Policy & Administrative Procedure 3540: Sexual and Other Assaults on Campus- first reading

items.item_details:
Per its adopted governing principles, the Board of Trustees will evaluate its performance at the end of each meeting.
	 
The Board will consider two items in discussing its evaluation:
	 
1.To ascertain the effectiveness of the meeting in attaining the advancement of the Board's Global Ends Policy.
	 
2.To ascertain the degree to which Trustees adhered to the Board adopted Governance Principle: Trustees Code of Conduct.
items.item_text: Board Meeting Evaluation
